titlestmt.titleproper: Finding Aid for the Lewis MacAdams papers LSC.2289

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-06-27 14:45:51 -0700.

physdesc.extent: (121 boxes, 5 half boxes, 2 flat boxes, 2 flat boxes oversize, 1 telescoping box)

did.abstract: Lewis MacAdams is a Los Angeles-based poet, journalist, and filmmaker, and has authored over 20 books of poems and stories. Collection materials include MacAdams' monographs; environmental and cultural journalism; film projects; correspondence with poets and artists; files related to the Friends of the Los Angeles River (FoLAR); performance materials from the San Francisco and Los Angeles poetry and arts scenes; publications from MacAdams' library, and personal memorabilia, as well as countless drafts and poetry fragments. MacAdams' work embraces performance art and political activism on behalf of local and national causes, and includes files related to the founding of FoLAR. His writings about the river, politics, culture, and crime have been published in Rolling Stone, the Los Angeles Times, and the L.A. Weekly.
did.physloc: Stored off-site. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
did.langmaterial: Materials are primarily in English, with some writing, correspondence, and performance materials in Spanish, Italian, French, and German.

accessrestrict.p: Open for research. All requests to access special collections materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Reproduction and Use
userestrict.p: Property rights to the objects belong to UCLA Library Special Collections. All other rights, including copyright, are retained by the creators and their heirs. It is the responsibility of the researcher to determine who holds the copyright and pursue the copyright owner or his or her heir for permission to publish where The UC Regents do not hold the copyright.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Lewis MacAdams papers (Collection 2289). UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Kelly Besser with assistance from Jade Finlinson, Gaku Uchino, and Rebecca Bucher, and supervision from Megan Hahn Fraser, 2017.

Collections are processed to a variety of levels depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived user interest and research value, availability of staff and resources, and competing priorities. Library Special Collections provides a standard level of preservation and access for all collections and, when time and resources permit, conducts more intensive processing. These materials have been arranged and described according to national and local standards and best practices.

We are committed to providing ethical, inclusive, and anti-racist description of the materials we steward, and to remediating existing description of our materials that contains language that may be offensive or cause harm. We invite you to submit feedback about how our collections are described, and how they could be described more accurately, by filling out the form located on our website: Report Problematic Content and Description in UCLA's Library Collections and Archives.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: Lewis MacAdams is a poet, journalist, and filmmaker whose work embraces performance art and political activism. Born October 12, 1944 and raised in Dallas, Texas, MacAdams earned a B.A. in English from Princeton in 1966 and a Master's degree from State University of New York, Buffalo in 1968. He participated in the poetry and performance scenes in Bolinas and San Francisco and was director of the Poetry Center at San Francisco State University from 1975-1978. After moving to Los Angeles, MacAdams concentrated on poetry and journalism as well as film and television projects, including a collaboration with EZTV founder John Dorr and the Lannan Foundation on a video series that featured readings by poets. He also wrote and performed with avant-garde artists like The Dark Bob and others in the Los Angeles performance scene. MacAdams founded Friends of the Los Angeles River (FOLAR) in 1986, which he describes as a "40-year art work" that aims to harness creative energies which engage politics, magic, and imagination "to bring the Los Angeles River, one of the most degraded rivers on earth, back to life." MacAdams has been married twice and has four children.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Collection materials include MacAdams' writings such as monographs, journalism, and film projects, correspondence with poets and artists, files related to the Friends of the Los Angeles River, performance materials and fliers from the Los Angeles poetry and art scenes, publications from MacAdams' library, and memorabilia. Materials also include interviews and transcripts for his book The Birth of The Cool: Beat, Bebop, and the American Avant-Garde about the cultural history of the idea of cool, and materials related to his unpublished biography of Rolling Stone magazine founder Jann Wenner. This collection contains scripts for television and film projects, including material related to his documentary What Happened to Kerouac? and other video projects in collaboration with EZTV founder John Dorr, as well as a near-complete run of WET magazine, for which MacAdams was editor from 1980-1982. Audiovisual materials include interviews by MacAdams, television and movie projects, and performances.

arrangement.head: Organization and Arrangement
arrangement.p:
This collection has been arranged in the following series based on preservation of the existing order and the imposition of an intellectual order:
1. Writing by MacAdams
2. Correspondence
3. FoLAR files
4. Performance materials
5. Publications
6. Memorabilia

relatedmaterial.head: Related Material
relatedmaterial.p: Friends of the Los Angeles River records, 1987-2013 (Collection 2215). Available at UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

Alexandra Garrett Papers and Records of the Beyond Baroque Foundation, 1965-1991 (Collection 1615). Available at UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.
Aram Saroyan Papers, 1965-1989 (Collection 991). Available at UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.
Wanda Coleman papers, 1960-2013 (Collection 2282). Available at UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

Allan H. Kurtzman Collection of Material about Beat Writers and Artists, ca. 1950-1989 (Collection 362). Available at UCLA Library Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, University of California, Los Angeles.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The poetry subseries includes poems by MacAdams written on a spectrum of surfaces.
Box 1 includes a folder of his resumes and biographies.
Boxes 6-8 include monographs by MacAdams.

Books from Lewis MacAdams' library that were originally donated with the papers have been individually cataloged in the UCLA Library online catalog. Records for these items may be found by searching the Special Coll/Archive SPAC "LMAC" using the Advanced search tab in the Library catalog, or keyword searching "Books from the Library of Lewis MacAdams."

Box 18: Thirteen 3.5" floppy disks.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: This subseries includes notes, manuscripts, research materials, interviews, publicity files, royalty statements, photographs, and proofs related to his book Birth Of The Cool: Beat, Bebop, and the American Avant Garde.
Box 12 includes a partially smoked marijuana joint.
Box 13 contains photo research materials including correspondence, illustrations, negatives, photographs, and permissions.

Box 18 includes interviews with Judith Malina, Fielding Dawson, Allen Ginsberg, Robert F. Kennedy Jr., and Lewis MacAdams. MacAdams discusses the book, the notion of how cool was an act of defiance starting amongst post-World War II African American Jazz musicians and how it spread to the cultural mainstream. This box also contains book chapters on floppy disks, a Birth Of The Cool MTV2 News segment, and a John Coltrane documentary.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: COLLECTION CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Audiovisual materials in this collection will require assessment and possible digitization for safe access. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
Box 24: One CD, two VHS, twenty-two microcassettes, and fifty-one Minidiscs.
Box 25: Nine VHS and 5 CDs.
Box 34: One CD and 1 DVD.

Box 28, folder 2: One 3.5" floppy disk.
Box 32, folder 1: One 3.5" floppy disk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Jann Wenner Biography subseries includes drafts, notes, correspondence, research files, interviews, transcripts, and monographs collected from the Wenner family.
Boxes 19-20 contain notes, questions, drafts, correspondence, and interview transcripts for the following: Jann Wenner, Kent Brownridge, Christine Doudna, Sarah Lazin, and Yoko Ono.

Box 21 contains notes and interview transcripts for Dallas Clark, David Felton, Merlyn Wenner Ruddell, and Sim Wenner. This box also includes a research files on Hunter S. Thompson and early Rolling Stone articles.
Boxes 22-23 contain notes, transcripts, drafts and correspondence with, Jann, Sim, and Kate Wenner. Box 22 includes a copy of Chester White Flippo's thesis Rock Journalism and Rolling Stone.

Box 24 includes a MTV News Special Report on Hate Rock, a MTV News Straight Dope Special Report On Drugs, and interviews with the following: Jann Wenner, Annie Leibovitz, Kent Brownridge, Sarah Lazin, Bob Wallace, Ahmet Ertegun, Mike Salisbury, Marianne Partridge, Elizabeth Schmidt, Charles M. Young, Cindy Ehrlich, Jac Holzman, Michael Douglas, Don Henley, Baron Wolman, Tom Wolfe, Juan Thompson, Yoko Ono, Jackson Browne, Sim Wenner, Clive Davis, Chet Helms, Dallas Clark, Merlyn Wenner Ruddell, Kate Wenner, and Laurel Gonsalves.

Box 25 includes Jann Wenner interviews, Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum (RRHOFAM) speeches, RRHOFAM opening weekend highlights, Vision & Triumph: How Cleveland Built the Rock Hall, Rolling Stone interview with Hunter S. Thompson, Rap with Ben Fong-Torres, Al Green Visits Rolling Stone, and "TVTV covers Rolling Stone 16mm Edition Show as it appeared on NET SHOW BEHIND THE LINES."
Box 26: Chapter drafts and Hunter S. Thompson memorial materials.
Box 27: Research files, drafts, notes, Kurt Loder file, and correspondence with Jamie Moran.
Box 28: Drafts and notes.
Box 29 contains RRHOFAM materials, a contacts file, correspondence, contracts, notes, and chapter drafts.
Box 30: RRHOFAM research file, chapter outlines, drafts, and notes.
Box 31 includes business cards, notes, drafts, Andrew Wylie emails, and Annie Leibovitz files.
Box 32: Drafts, book proposal, chapter outlines, and synopsis of the Wenner biography titled Jann Wenner and his Time.
Box 33: Drafts, outlines, notes, and research materials.
Box 34: Chapter drafts, notes, and an Rolling Stone ex-employee reunion file which includes an RSX Stories CD and the RSX Antacid Flashback DVD.
Box 35: Monographs by Sim Wenner, Kate Wenner, and Margaret Lee Chadwick.

Books from Lewis MacAdams' library that were originally donated with the papers have been individually cataloged in the UCLA Library online catalog. Records for these items may be found by searching the Special Coll/Archive SPAC "LMAC" using the Advanced search tab in the Library catalog, or keyword searching "Books from the Library of Lewis MacAdams."
Box 36: Margaret Lee Chadwick's Chadwick School yearbooks 1959-1964.

Box 41: One MiniDisc, and four 5.25" floppy disks that contain the following titles: Love Stories, Show Coalition, Mother Jones, Rest of the Story, L.A. Suspicions, Harvard School, John Dorr, Poetry Championships, Jesse Jackson, and Resume.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Journalism subseries includes article proposals, notes, research materials, audio recordings, interview transcripts, drafts, clippings, and periodicals.

Box 37 includes the following files: Friends of Mark Nathanson, World Heavyweight Poetry Championship, Pot Wars, Jeremiah of the Palms, History of the Sunset Strip, On Burroughs Work, and Love Conquers Zen.

Box 38 contains the following files: Buddhist Things, Zen Biz, Notre Dame of Buddhism, Robert Smithson Biography, Anjelica Houston, Tilth, Johnny Rotten, Jackie Goldberg, MOCA, John Milius, Robert Mitchum, Suzanne, Lacy, and Ed Sanders.

Box 39 includes files for Urban Coyote, Sunshine Muse, The Ambassador from E.L.A., "The Rookie," "Selling of L.A. County," "How is the Sailboat Art?," L.A. Weekly, "Blendo Manifesto," and WET Magazine. Folder 1 contains his "Ode to Sylvester" and folder 14 includes his L.A. Weekly Reporter's Notebook.
Box 40 includes "Blendo Manifesto," "Truckstop Portraits," and "The 710 Split."
Box 41 includes recordings on audio cassette of Timothy Leary, Cassandra Wilson, Kim Jones, Joe Biroc, R.D. Laing, Hal Ezell, Steve Gibson, and Thom Mount as well as articles on floppy discs.

bioghist.head: Biography/History
bioghist.p: MacAdams was an editor at WET from 1980-1982. Venice-based artist and designer Leonard Koren launched WET: The Magazine of Gourmet Bathing in 1976, an extension of his work creating "bath events" and "unusual bath environments" that began while earning a Master's degree in Architecture and Urban Planning from UCLA in 1972. Koren ceased publication of WET after a five-year run, but continued to create work dedicated to bathing, including a history of his signature magazine titled Making Wet: The Magazine of Gourmet Bathing.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Issues of WET Magazine from Lewis MacAdams' library that were originally donated with the papers have been individually cataloged in the UCLA Library online catalog. Records for these items may be found by searching the Special Coll/Archive SPAC "LMAC" using the Advanced search tab in the Library catalog, or keyword searching "Books from the Library of Lewis MacAdams."
Box 39 contains ephemera related to WET, including postcards and bookmarks, and a business card for MacAdams with WET logo.

did.unittitle: Whole Life Times, v. 26, no. 4. Malibu.
Wind Bell, v. 16, no. 1. San Francisco.
Yolanda Pipeline's Magazine. Boulder and Palo Alto.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The film and television projects subseries includes:
Boxes 58-61: What Happened to Kerouac? materials include scripts, research files, notebooks, correspondence, reviews, posters, and audiovisual materials.
Box 62-65: Scripts, screen plays, teleplays, drafts, research files, notes, outlines, and critiques for Landslide by Lesley Taplin and MacAdams.
Box 65, folders 11-12 contain drafts of Banana Republic screenplay by MacAdams and Cheech Marin.
Box 66 contains audiovisual materials related to In the Garden Ring and Live From the 21st Century.
Box 67 contains EZTV materials concerning its history, Bogosian's Fun House, and Sushi Ole as well as John Hall Dorr poems 1978-1985.
Box 68: Billy Rader screenplay drafts.
Box 69: Only One Swims Away or Man Bites Shark script drafts.
Box 70: Script drafts, treatments, and notes for China Girl by Lesley Taplin and MacAdams and The Last Days of Hank Williams by Boz Scaggs and MacAdams.
Box 71: Tokyo script drafts.
Box 72: Tokyo drafts, correspondence, and a L.A. Sands file.

Box 73: Files for the following projects: Dark Bob, Black and White, The Rest of the Story (Young Americans), The Legend of the Mexican Kitchen, My Traitor's Heart, They Brought the Water, and Virginia Dare treatment by Lesley Taplin and MacAdams.
Box 74: Files for various projects including California One, Andrei Toluzakov, History of Rock and Roll, and History of TV.
Box 130: Kerouac poster mock up board and original print.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The correspondence series has been organized by the last name of the sender and includes personal and professional letters.

Box 80 includes correspondence from family, Alexandra Garrett, Eric Garcetti, Allen Ginsberg, and Tom Hayden.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This box also includes anonymous correspondence and letters with first names only.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The Friends of the Los Angeles River (FoLAR) series documents the 40-year art project started by MacAdams in 1986 to promote creative solutions and policies to return the Los Angeles River to its original wild state. The materials include original artwork by FoLAR collaborators for publicizing cleanup events, correspondence between MacAdams and local politicians and activists, materials related to the Not A Cornfield project, and photographs and certificates relating to MacAdams environmental activism.

All requests to access processed audiovisual materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

COLLECTION CONTAINS DIGITAL MATERIALS: Special equipment or further processing may be required for viewing. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files include Battle of the Bards materials and TPC programs, press, notes, and correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files include articles, correspondence, attendee lists, and performance agreements.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Box 96: Files include Beyond Baroque, PEN, Allen Ginsberg: Celebration of Life, Bisbee Poetry Festival, Naropa Institute, Performing Tree, workshop and art exhibition materials.
Box 97, folder 4: Performance programs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Box 61: Posters for the following: California Arts Council ‚Äì A writer for everyone, Art LA '89 ‚Äì 4th Int'l Contemporary Art Fair, Vittorio Sella Summit and P70 One World Poetry Amsterdam.
Box 88, folder 2: Posters for events featuring MacAdams and others. This folder includes a San Francisco Poetry Center poster designed by Johanna Drucker.
Box 97: Files include Lewis MacAdams flyers and posters as well as others such as X, Tim Miller, Dark Bob, and Dennis Cooper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Box 99 contains administrative files for the Lannan Literary series.
Boxes 100-105: Lannan Literary Series VHS tapes.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: COLLECTION CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Audiovisual materials in this collection will require assessment and possible digitization for safe access. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
Box 99, folder 6: One Beirut 7 inch record with Lewis, Dark Bob, and others.
Box 100: Thirteen VHS
Box 101: Thirteen VHS
Box 102: Thirteen VHS
Box 103: Thirteen VHS
Box 104: Thirteen VHS
Box 105: Thirteen VHS

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Audiovisual materials for Tao Poetry Circus.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: COLLECTION CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Audiovisual materials in this collection will require assessment and possible digitization for safe access. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
Box 106: Two U-Matic tapes, 9 VHS tapes, and 1 Betamax tape.
Box 107: Three VHS tapes, 19 CDs, 1 Beirut 7-inch LP record (45).
Box 108: Forty-one audio cassettes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Books collected by Lewis MacAdams that were donated with his papers have been individually cataloged in the UCLA Library online catalog. Records for these items may be found by searching the Special Coll/Archive SPAC "LMAC" using the Advanced search tab in the Library catalog, or keyword searching "Books from the Library of Lewis MacAdams."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Books from Lewis MacAdams' library that were originally donated with the papers have been individually cataloged in the UCLA Library online catalog. Records for these items may be found by searching the Special Coll/Archive SPAC "LMAC" using the Advanced search tab in the Library catalog, or keyword searching "Books from the library of Lewis MacAdams."

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: This collection contains both processed and unprocessed audiovisual materials. For information about the access status of the material that you are looking for, refer to the Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements note at the series and file levels. All requests to access processed audiovisual materials must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Files include Bolinas Life, Hearsay News, divorce paperwork, art created by his kids, Foster Child Advocate Services (FOCAS), and material related St. Mark's School in Dallas.
Box 130: Paradise Valley Environmental Impact Report, two copies of The Best Harvard Plays books of 1988-1989 with monographs for Lewis and Lee MacAdams.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: COLLECTION CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Audiovisual materials in this collection will require assessment and possible digitization for safe access. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.

COLLECTION CONTAINS DIGITAL MATERIALS: Special equipment or further processing may be required for viewing. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
Box 123, folder 2: One 3.5 inch floppy disk.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs of friends, family, and life in Bolinas.
Box 126 contains photos of MacAdams and includes his baby book.
Box 130: Oversize black and white photo of MacAdams in Bolinas.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: COLLECTION CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Audiovisual materials in this collection will require assessment and possible digitization for safe access. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
Box 124: Two VHS tapes.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Plaques commemorate MacAdams and his family.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials include planners and calendars.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials include badges, business cards, and buttons.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Awards and commendations.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Lesley Gilb Taplin, Jim Carroll, and Joanne Kyger.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: COLLECTION CONTAINS AUDIOVISUAL MATERIALS: Audiovisual materials in this collection will require assessment and possible digitization for safe access. All requests to access special collections material must be made in advance using the request button located on this page.
Box 129, folder 5: Two Lesley Gilb Taplin family DVDs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials include a Nudie's one sheet, a George Foreman vs. Muhammad Ali World Heavyweight Championship ticket, a Hubert Gerold Brown Wanted by the FBI poster, Californians for BROWN (1978) bumper stickers, a ZZ Top caricature of the band signed by Billy Gibbons, and Cops Bust Gangster - Heap No Good! bumper stickers from Jessica Hagedorn and the Gangster Choir at the Poetry Center, San Francisco.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Box 88 contains a We Remember the Hands of the Generations/Recordamos las Manos de las Generaciones poster in support of the College Dream Fund.

Box 129 includes a Rauschenberg flag, bicycle screen print, Edmund Shea poster, Kora in Hell revisionist project, ballpoint ink drawings, Solidarity Vietnam piece, Lewis' 60th birthday art, and Japanese colored paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Materials include recordings of Rhea, Marjorie, Marion MacAdams, Ocean Lee, Willie Blaze, Phoebe, Kyle, and Seth. This box also includes a River Boy t-shirt.
